bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harry Clemons, August 10, 1939

div1.p: Kean thanks Clemons for referring him to the article about Moran by Furnas. Kean then corrects Furnas' claim that yellow fever disappeared in Cuba in 1901, when it was actually 1908. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harry Clemons, August 10, 1939
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
August 10/39
My dear Mr. Clemons
div1.p:
It was very thoughtful of
you to call my attention to Mr.
Furnas's article on J. J. Moran.
It is amusingly written and has
fewer errors than most newspaper
writings on the Y. F. & Walter Reed
episode. I dont think that Dr. Roger
Post Ames was a Univ. Va. man-
he was certainly a quite uncultured
specimen whom Reed took on because
he claimed to be a yellow fever immune
I know him well, as he looked after
me when I had yellow fever in June
1900.
2.
And of course the statement on p. 35
“But Havana has know nothing of yellow
fever since Johnny Moran left there
in 1901.” is incorrect by seven years.
I heard Dr. Franklin Martin, President of
the American College of Surgeons make
the same statement in an address here
in Washington. The facts are that it
disappeared in 1901 but reappeared in
1904 during the breakdown of the Cuban
Government and spread far more
widely over the Island than it had
ever done before, due to the large
non-immune immigration of the years
1900 - 1906. As Health Officer of Cuba in
the second American Military Intervention
Oct. 1905 to Feb. 1906 I spent most of
my time in its second conquest which
was completed in 1908.
div1.closer: Cordially your friend J.R. Kean Don't trouble to answer this at none is needed.
